intro: Chaenactis aurea, commonly known as the golden paintbrush, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and hairy stems. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and alpine environments, thriving in high-altitude regions. Its bright yellow flowers bloom in the spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Chaenactis aurea is often found in open meadows and is adapted to withstand harsh environmental conditions.
